head_text.subj: EXT. A STATION, A SMALL HOTEL, A SMALL TOWN,

text: It is not snowing and the night sky is overcast but the s on the ground gives off enough light -- using infra-red i need be -- to establish the station (extreme l.s.), the h (dead center), the edge of the town (extreme r.s.). Even darkness the hotel gives off something odd and curdled. B and between these buildings, as our eyes become accustome to the darkness, we see an immense perspective of snowed  land, and a very distant low horizon against a black sky  which holds two thirds of the screen. HOLD THIS DARKNESS perhaps eight seconds Then, within a  maximum thirty seconds, the darkness alters through the l of pre-dawn, dawn, etc., to the light of late morning. At the proper early juncture, one or two small lights appear windows, and go out again. At the edge of the town, in th earliest real daylight, a man's tiny figure comes out of door and walks out of r.s. Little flags of smoke and stea sprout, compact and crisp, in the bitter air. Shading and detail become increasingly clear. The station is coal-bla its sign FORT ROMPER, is just readable. The town is mostl low, mean, frame construction -- the drab shades of tired blotting-paper. The Hotel, of a disturbing shade even in  darkness, gives off under the changing light an always mo and more sinister and unearthly fish-belly glare. Its sig PALACE HOTEL, is newish, and easy to read. It is a crummy rather frail-looking wooden building of two stories, crow by florid cornice work. Beyond these buildings we can see perhaps forty miles. Th sky is dull gray; the snow is like rice; there are farms, lonely distances apart. When high, shadowless morning light is established, the t silhouette of a man -- SCULLY -- walks briskly out of the Hotel front door and towards the station. o.s., begin and bring up SOUNDS of an overworked locomotive and a train; walks faster; bring up the SOUNDS; he trots; a somewhat  archaic locomotive, crusted and bearded with ice and snow slowing, drags on from l.s. a baggage car, a daycoach, th first of a string of boxcars; covering SCULLY as he trots stopping. As quickly as will not be be absurd, SCULLY  reappears, walking towards the Hotel, followed by the COW the EASTERNER, the SWEDE, in single file. At the same mom the CAMERA, which is centered on the hotel door, starts  towards the door at their pace, holding them within left- screen. We get at first only character by silhouette and  near-silhouette, then in more detail. SCULLY is in the lead, half-turning as he walks, to talk; short, chunky, late middle-aged. Next, the COWBOY, size a structure of John Wayne, tight city trousers, a solid blo of mackinaw, his best hat; he walks like a horseman and w the stooping, rather diffident stride of a man of his hei he carries a scarred raw-hide suitcase or a splotched Hol hide roll-grip. Next, the EASTERNER. He is small, slender bears himself well and entirely without the bumptiousness so many small men. Without at all mincing, he is more nea footed along the icy boards than the others are; he carri a briefcase and a middle-sized, neutral valise, possibly  with faded labels on it. Last, the SWEDE: He is above ave height but stocky enough to seem shorter than he is, and  disturbed and scared enough, as a rule, to sag an inch or two more. A shiny black leather coat to the middle of the thighs, trousers which look as if he had on two suits of  long underwear beneath them, a cap of coarse hairy wool, sizes too small, high on his head, with earflaps which at best cannot thoroughly cover his ears. There is something shaky, equivocal and arythmic about his walking. An outsi new suitcase which looks to be covered by black oilcloth  increases his clumsiness at the knees. As these men grow out of silhouette into detail and size, and we begin to hear their SOUNDS, the CHOWF-CHOWFINGS of the locomotive, o.s., drown out these SOUNDS and the  locomotive and the train, gathering speed, cut off the me from view and then fill most of the screen, the Hotel sti jutting above. As locomotive makes r.s., the CAMERA is qu close to train and place-names, emblems and names of line swinging by, suggest the whole nation and continent in  geography and history.

The CAMERA is still creeping, lowering quietly to eye hei o.s. SOUNDS of walking on icy boards. The four men enter, in single file and in the same order, at l.s. SCULLY step pace past his door and wheels and stops abruptly, bowing  slightly and flinging out one hand in a slightly uneasy p of Mine Host and causing the others to stop or tread wate in uneasy courtesy, indulging his spiel. The CAMERA stops creeping at the same moment; they are medium close. The  EASTERNER looks quietly and curiously at the strange colo
(politely concealing  his faint nausea) I've never seen the shade before,  but once.
(a little jealous,  but very polite) And where might that be, may I ask?
On the legs of a kind of heron; one  of the wading birds. It's a very  strange color; there's nothing else  quite like it in Nature. It declares  the bird's position against any  background.

Declares his -- does it now! Well  now, surely that's a mischievous hue  for the Almighty to paint a poor  craytcher in this murderin' world.  Declare me position indeed. Aginst  inny background. That's nicely put.  That's it in a nutshell. You kin see  the Palace Hotel for miles up the  line, all weathers, and she's starin'  like the morning star. Now didn't  ye? And do ye truly admire it?
It's a very remarkable shade.

Ahh, count on a traveled man for  connisewership! But gintlemen, may  heaven forgive me an' me guests  rattlin' their teeth on me own  doorstep. (he hurries to open  the door and wave  them past him) Come in! Come in! (to Johnnie) One twenty-two three an' -- No, line  'em up along the south corridor and  don't let the grass grow under yer  feet. Hang yer coats in here,  gintlemen, unless ye prefer to go  straight to yer rooms.
No. -- No, thanks.

(continuing) Let's thaw ourselves out a bit; ye  can sign up at yer layzhure. Not  that ev'ry room in me establishment  ain't as warm as toast, gintlemen,  but in weather the likes o' this, ye  should have the binifit o' the lee  o' house.
Sure. -- Of course, thanks.

Now here's something, friends, ye  couldn't hope to find in the Waldorf.  Ye see? (he pours a slashing  tinkle of ice- splintery water into  the first basin) What would ye git there? (contemptuously) Shteem! Where fer the chills there's  nuthin' on earth to set the blood  hummin' agin like a bit o' nice brisk  water. (Meantime, he is  filling two more  basins) Ye don't believe me? (to the Easterner) Don't be shy! try it! You'll see. (The Easterner plunges;  the instant the water  hits his face he  utters four sharp  coughs, but he stays  at it and emerges  gasping and groping;  Scully produces a  towel he grabbed  from a shelf under  the tub and now says  with an air of great  graciousness) Yer towel, sir.
Yer towel, sir. (same old towel)
DOLLY along to the Swede, eyes downcast and shifting a li he plants his heavy fingers in the water up to their seco knuckles, and quickly withdraws them, quailing profoundly
(handing out the towel,  now quite draggled,  politely but with  less enthusiasm) Yer towel, sir.
The Swede sinks one finger at a time into the towel and  twists.
He is looking into a mirror. His skin shines as if he had used some kind of metal polish on it; he is quietly surpr and pleased. He glances down casually to see if his nails are clean.

Also gazing into the mirror. He has the same burnished lo of metal polished. Impersonal light eyes, a little bit bo very virile and empty, fixed through most of the shot on hair, which he is tidying with a public comb. His eyes ra down, casually and impersonally across his face at the fi of the shot.

He is twisting his fingers, one by one, heavily in the to by the angle of his eyes and their surreptition, it is cl that he is very carefully watching the other three men in the mirror. At the end of the shot, Scully walks into it the Swede drops the towel beside the basin. The Swede tur for the door, Scully picks up the towel, tosses it into a cardboard box, CAMERA SWINGING as they make for the door.
(in re the towel) Thank you. (calling after them) Now just make yerselves comfortable  by the stove, gintlemen. It won't be  no time till dinner.
They start through the door.
Past stove on the FARMER as he glances up and starts to e back his chair to make room.
Mean weather.
Mean enough.
Seven below, last night.
That a fact.
Warmed up a leetle, but it's jest  makin' fer more snow.
Snowin' a'ready.
Big wind acomin' too, shouldn't  wonder.
Shouldn't wonder.
No sir, shouldn't wonder if we git  us a real ole fashion' blizzard. If  ye don't mind my askin', stranger,  where might ye be from?
I was down to Omahaw; a little  business.
An' where might ye be headin'?
Got me a little ranch, up near the  Dakota line.
That a fact? Stoppin' over fer the  Spur train, 's 'at right?
That's right.
Myself, I'm a farmer.
That right?
Yup. That's right. Started as a  homesteader, back in seventy-six,  but now I own muh land.
Uh huh.
Quarter section.
That right?
Yup. Quarter section. When I come  here it warn't nuthin' but a untamed  wilderness like you might say. But  now I own me a quarter section.
A silence. Farmer spits again, then addresses the Eastern
An' what might yer own business be,  stranger, if ye don't mind my askin'?
Not at all, sir. I'm a journalist.  Newspaper man.
Now is that a fact? (carefully) Not meaning no offense, you're from  the east, ain't you?
(smiling) Yes. (against his natural  reticence) A Philadelphia paper.
Is that right now. Well, not meanin'  no offense, I'm mighty glad to hear  that.
(smiling) Why's that, sir?

I was skeered ye might be from Noo  York City. Not that I've ever laid  eyes on one, an' o' course, it could  be I heared wrong. But what ye hear  tell... (a half silent  whistling whew with  a shake of the head) ...them Noo Yorkers! (Uneasy glance at the  Swede; tactful change  of subject) But they ain't never nuthin' happens  out here, Mister, not that's fer the  nooze papers. -- Is they?

Well, you see, I'm not after news  stories just now. (politely) Back east we're all so ignorant of  the rest of the country, that's all.  I am too, and I don't like to be  ignorant. I just want to learn what  things are really like, If I can,  and tell others who don't know, you  see.
(chews it over,  interested but puzzled) An' they'll pay ye a livin' fer that?
(smiling) That's right.
But if ye don't mind me askin', why  how come ye coms to Rawmpr? Ain't  nuthin' ever happens here.
(careful and very  polite but candid) Frankly I didn't know I was getting  off till I got here. Seeing it from  the train, I just felt I couldn't go  on by without seeing more of the  Blue Hotel.
Blue Hotel! Oh! You mean right where  we're sett'n'?
The Easterner nods, smiling.
Well, I ain't no proper jedge, but  the woman, she thinks it's mighty  purty.
I never saw a color like it. Not on  a hotel.
Is that a fact now? Well I'll be  dogged. (pause. To the Swede) An' how 'bout you, Mister, if ye  don't mind me askin'? Where might  you be from?

CAMERA VERTICAL over the dining table, starting at the he pulling down along the aisle of places moderately slow.  Perhaps one or two heads ad lib into the shot, ducking ov the plate for a bite, but except for this, heads are not  visible -- only what is on the table, and the busily eati and reaching hands. Subdued SOUNDS of shy, speechless, hu eating. The food is all on the table and by evidence of d done, we are well on into the meal. Voices are very spora and ad lib, possibly recognizable; close to monosyllabic wholly utilitarian except for the Easterner.
Meat please... Pass the potatoes...  Turnips.
They are passed, used and returned without comment. A han and fork reach to spear a biscuit.
Could I have the butter, please.
An almost inaudible "Sure," in reply and
(quietly) Thanks.

The voices are o.s., such hands as reach deeper into the  terrain than the eating plates, appear at unpredictable a and rhythms; perhaps two might also collide and spring ap with the almost electric-shock celerity of shy courtesy. more than ten seconds to this VERTICAL PULL before we beg to hit barren space, the tundra-like lower reaches of the table, all much-mended, not perfectly clean, white tablec no places set. After just a little of this, CAMERA begins tilt and settle so that as it reaches the end of the long table, (room for a crowded 14) it is at eye level of a se man looking up the center of the table at Scully at the h Along l.s., the Swede (next Scully), and Johnnie; r.s., t Cowboy, (next to Scully) then the Easterner and the Farme We pause just long enough to get a glimpse of Scully's  character through his eating: a business-like but rather  frugal and finicky eater, even a touch of old-maidishness an old fashioned and rather cute old guy; absorbed in eat he loses entirely his Mine Host mannerisms, he's just an  aging pappy at home, reloading. Rather frail eyelids and  stretched neck when he drinks water; an evidently self-ta but deeply habitual care to take small bites and to keep lips closed over his chewing; dabby with his fork; delica at harpooning a biscuit; a suggestion of dental plates wh don't quite fit.

A big napkin is tied under his ears, its knot-ends make s ears below his own. He is sweating a little. He uses his  fork left-handed and upside down, European style. He eats steadily with heavy square gestures, and we see in his ea and chewing a conflict between the hunger of a fairly hea eater and his uneasiness. He is intensely silent and his  eyes are darting all over the joint with a dog's eating- vigilance plus his own special kind of uneasiness. Elbows wide and clumsy, he usually grazes Johnnie and as CAMERA  pulls to the left losing the Swede and picking up Johnnie the elbows collide rather hard and the first we see of  Johnnie's face involves a spasm of annoyance.
The Cowboy is winking at Johnnie, amused.

He watches the Swede. A small, sour smile, friendly eyes, reaction to the Cowboy. His eating is the normal fast hea eating of a not very well mannered, far from meek, kid,  exactly on the watershed between being a boy and a very y man.

A napkin tucked fairly high into his dark shirt, his larg elbows held in with unaccustomed tightness. His eating sy is to mash whatever can be mashed into malleable material mix it, load his fork by help of his knife as heavy as  possible, sculpture and trim it with his knife; changes f to right hand, brings it up to a mouth which opens for it and closes over it as efficiently as a steamshovel, then  working his full jaws with a fair amount of SOUND which h keeps reasonably subdued, meanwhile lowering his fork,  changing hands, and starting all over again. He swallows  exactly as soon as the new load is ready and takes a swal of water just before shifting the fork to the right hand: solid machine-like reciprocation between knife, fork, lef hand, right hand, mouth and water glass. Otherwise, as a  rule, his eyes are either attentive to his plate, or out focus. PULL CAMERA TO THE RIGHT, losing the Cowboy and picking u the Easterner: his are the ordinary eating manners of a w brought-up middle-class Easterner, shaded by his own  considerable natural elegance. The modestly hearty appeti of a small healthy man. Small, strong, fine hands. As wit his way of speaking, he neither obtrudes nor tries to con or modify what is natural to him or to his background. He a clear master at seeing everything there is to be seen  without appearing to stare, or to sneak glances, or even look, or even to be careful not to look. As the CAMERA le him, PULLING RIGHT, he touches his mouth with his napkin, which has been in his lap. TAIL OFF briefly on the Farmer, napkin tucked broad over of overalls, hard, heavy-knuckled red-looking hands: look at nobody; hoeing it in; an aging, hard working countryma at home at this table, and unself-conscious of strangers.

head_text.subj: THE WHOLE TABLE FROM THE EMPTY END

text: They are all eating slower, the tail-end of the meal. AD and unobtrusively behind this, is Scully's daughter movin waiting on table, silently. She is a pale, melancholic, p once-pretty spinster of about 30. By-play and reaction be her and the diners should be present but minimal, and pla ad lib in passing, never pointed up. Scully rearranges himself to lean back in his chair and p his hands on the table. A heavy silence as they dab at th food.
His eyes angle sharply to the Cowboy and then to the  Easterner.

head_text.subj: THE EASTERNER AND THE COWBOY FROM SWEDE'S ANG

text: The Easterner catches the Swede's eye, looks quickly down The Cowboy's eyes up; down. The Easterner looks up again  with an inevitable tinge of surreptition.
The Swede is disturbed by the Easterner's look; glances  sharply to the Cowboy.

head_text.subj: THE EASTERNER AND THE COWBOY FROM SWEDE'S ANG

text: The Cowboy looks up with inevitable surreptition.
The Swede is still more worried. Gives Scully a sharp gla
He looks up at the worried look, quickly down again; up a slyly.
Eyes sidelong to Johnnie, very sly and worried, then to t Easterner and the Cowboy, intensely suspicious and deeply worried.

head_text.subj: THE EASTERNER AND THE COWBOY FROM THE SWEDE'S

text: The Cowboy looks up in flat perplexity; the Easterner loo up in curiosity so veiled it looks almost criminal; then looks down; then the Easterner and the Cowboy glance towa each other, each rather secretly, checking if the other h noticed anything odd; it looks very much like complicity.
Very deeply bothered, he rakes his glance at each man in  turn, then sharply up at the wall above Scully.

The Swede's eyes leave the engraving, quick glances all a again; he is sweating. He looks into his plate and at his heavy hands on either side of it. He is working hard to b himself, he begins to get brave and to resolve himself; a last he determines to speak.
(to Scully) Me, I come from New York City.
The Swede casts quick somber eyes at the Farmer.

head_text.subj: THE FARMER FROM THE SWEDE'S ANGLE

text: His fork hesitates a fraction near his mouth and goes in  fast. The Farmer looks oven more absorbedly into his plat
(juicily polite) Do ye now! Now isn't that intristin'!  Isn't that fascinatin'! A great city.  Ah a great city. Well I remember me  own arrival.
You come from New York too?
No, I only seen it fer a matter of  days.
The daughter passes behind them; bread pudding to each.
My home was Bahstin Mass.
Every one quietly starting to eat dessert.
I lived there ten years.
Tin yearrs. Ye don't say. Tin years.  A great city.
Before that I come from Sweden.
Ye don't say. Fine people, the Swedes.
In New York I was a tailor.
A tayylor! Ye don't say! A tailor ye  say. Now isn't that simply  fascinatin'. (to the table at large) The gintleman here tells me he was a  tailor. Isn't that intristin'!
Yah: tailor.

Well sir, tailorin' I never learned.  Ye might call me a jack of all trades  and master o' none, exceptin'  hotelkeeping... (laughs modestly,  glancing hopefully  around the table) ...but tailorin', no, that's a mystery  to me... It must be a fascinatin'  trade.
(dead silence)
Hard on the eyes, maybe.
(More silence; his  eyes go again to  Scully; a kind of  suspicion is in them,  and in his voice) How long you been here?
Fourteen years this last August I  came here and I never had cause to  regret it. A good town, sir. Good  neighbors.
Scully beams a little nervously, glancing around.
What are the crops?

Wheat, sir. That's the main crop, ye  might say the only crop. Wheat. (Eyes and polite  gesture to angle of  Farmer) Here's a man kin tell ye all there  is to know about wheat, can't ye  Henry? Henry's a wheat farmer.
The Cowboy and the Easterner are eating very quietly. The Farmer nods, saying nothing.
Splindid soil. Rich as cheese. Some  farms here, the yield is up to thirty- five bushels to the acre. (to the Farmer) Isn't that correct?
The Farmer nods.

Last summer at the best it brought  20 cents a bushel. So ye can readily  see it's a prosperous community. (A rather wretched  smile) Plain but prosperous. (More silence) There are farmers hereabouts who are  to be accounted as wealthy men. (Silence) Farmers, mind ye. (To table at large,  almost pleadingly) Wealthy!
Appalled, his glasses wobble on his nose. SOUND of Swede' laughter o.s.

The Cowboy's jaw hangs open as if he were dead; in the  Easterner, a far more sophisticated astonishment and  wondering; the Farmer scowls more with puzzlement than an all dead silent, hands of all three arrested; continue Sw laughter o.s.
Laughing and gleaming and glinting at them in great amuse and a glitter of fear.

Towards Scully. Everyone motionless and silent except the Swede, all heads gawping at him: he is rocking with laugh and quietly raising his heavy hands an inch from the tabl and slapping them down again, over and over.

head_text.subj: THROUGH THE FRONT WINDOW OF THE MAIN ROOM

text: Extreme violence of snow and wind, the only visual anchor is a blanched gate post leaning rigid into it. SOUNDS of  strong wind, shut away, and of snow against the window pa PULL BACK as Scully's aging hand releases a harsh ornate  lace curtain he has pulled back, and BACK PAST SCULLY tur his face in CLOSE UP from the window, smiling, and announ to the room at large:
A real old-fashioned blizzard,  gintlemen. (Almost proprietary  about it)

head_text.subj: DOWN THE ROOM FROM SCULLY'S ANGLE

text: They are all filing in from the dining room past the stov in the profoundly relaxed few moments of shapeless drifti after a satisfying meal. In their whole demeanor and tone voice there is absolute security; total lack of personal  connection with the blizzard except the pleasure of being indoors.
(forward along l.s.  and drifting toward  the center) I should say it is. (he continues leisurely  across the room  fishing in his pocket  for a cigarette)
The Cowboy is a little behind the Easterner.
Sure looks like it.

A little right of center he slowly turns his back, gettin out tobacco sack and papers. The Easterner by now is ligh up. The Swede walks much more slowly, beveling almost str toward the CAMERA, deeper towards us than any of the othe eyes on angle of window; slowly prodding tobacco into his pipe. His comment is a scarcely audible breathing; in his face is already the beginning of a strange excitement as watches through the window and approaches it.
(with a strange,  private excitement,  almost a whisper) Yaahh!

The Farmer, meanwhile, swings in just behind the chairs a the stove. He utters the quiet gasp of total belly- satisfaction, an "ahhh" not unlike Titus Moody's to Fred  Allen, but earthier. He is loosening his belt and content fingering through a gap in his shirt to scratch his belly Johnnie is in, silent, between the chair and the stove. T Easterner starts glancing at the news headlines; the Cowb starts slowly toward the stove; the Swede continues very  ponderously and slowly toward the CAMERA and the window.
(sharply) Johnnie! Lay on more coal.

head_text.subj: PAST EASTERNER TOWARD JOHNNIE BACK OF COWB

text: Want to burn the place down?
The Easterner turns to face the room. CUT IN MID-TURN.
Advancing from the window and leaning to peer toward the  stove.
Sure, it's rid hot now.
He comes down to the middle of the room, the CAMERA with  him, losing the Swede, still talking.
(continuing) I tell ye, friends, there's nuthin'  like a chair beside a stove...
His eyes and head following Scully who is already out of  shot toward the stove. The Easterner is lazily and happil observant.
(o.s.) ...to make ye shpit 'n the eye...
MEDIUM SHOT -- FROM EASTERNER'S ANGLE TOWARD SCULLY and t group coalescing toward the stove.
(back to CAMERA) ...o' the worst weather Heaven kin  send.
(absently; contentedly) That's right.
The startling SOUND, o.s., of hollowed palms being clappe together.
Pipe clenched, a queer grin on his face, just finishing h handclap of solitary excitement and pleasure.
Much interested, his eyes flick from the Swede's angle to the angle of the stove and the group; the newspaper droop in his hand.

head_text.subj: GROUP AT STOVE FROM EASTERNER'S ANGLE

text: They have noticed nothing.
Well, I'll be off about me dooties  if you'll excuse me gintlemen.
Sure. So long.
(o.s.) Certainly.
Scully crosses up the room toward l.s. CAMERA FOLLOWING,  losing the group.
(o.s.) How 'bout it? Ready to get skinned  alive again?
Son, day I see you skin a gopher  I'll deed ye my farm, an' my old  woman throwed in.
SOUND of a squeaky hinge across this.
Going through the little swinging gate by the registratio desk.
Be good thing for your land and a  mercy for your wife.
Ouch!
(approaching the table) Jest get busy with that skinnin',  son, loud talk never proved nuthin'.
(swinging chair into  place) I want to see this.
The Easterner walks into the shot as they severally arran chairs, cards and chips and start to settle down.

Farmer sits in original position; Johnnie nearest the coa and with his back to it. They are cutting for deal and th Cowboy and the Easterner, who are doing the last necessar hiking of chairs, look on.
His rigid, leaning stance has been four feet or so from t window. He is now very close to the window and is just pu under himself a small stool. o.s. THE SOUND of the oily w of expert shuffling.

The window is beyond him, his eyes are fixed deep into th snow. o.s. SOUNDS of dealing and ad lib bidding. CAMERA P SLOWLY around so that the Swede is in still larger close filling most of the screen. He is looking out intensely p the CAMERA, giving tiny, rapid pulls on his pipe; his fac showing signs of an inexplicable excitement; eyes becomin almost dreamy. CAMERA SLOWLY TURNS square on the window t focus on what his eyes are fixed on, -- the post. Storm S UP and card SOUNDS FADING to inaudibility. DISSOLVE to sn higher on post and, almost immediately, A LOUD SLAPPING D OF CARDS and the Farmer's angry voice and the scrape of a chair.
Deep fright and guile in the face and a strange and malig smile.
He is just finishing standing up, a look of heated scorn his face.
Too bad. Poor feller just ought to  leave cards alone. (They nod; they are  wholly on his side) Or his temper, one or the other.
That's right. Ye can't afford a  temper, not if ye play much cards.
Or cards, if you have a temper.
(chuckles) Mister, ya got sumpn' there.
How 'bout a whirl at four-handed; or  do you reckon we can keep from bitin'  each other's heads off?
(heavy jocosity) Buster, my gun's right on the table  so don't try nuthin' fancy.
(smiling with Cowboy) We might draw up a treaty of non- aggression.
Reckon I'll throw in with you,  Johnnie, you look like a mean man to  have agin ye.
(in a low voice) Better make sure the Swede'll play.
Hey buddy.
Hey Mister.
I beg your pardon.
Hehnh?
I wondered if you'd be my par --
How 'bout a little game?
Uneasy but determined to show everyone that he is not afr
Yeh? What kind of a game?
High Five.
Never heard of it.
Some call it Cinch.
Ain't no cinch the way that poor  Farmer plays it.
Some call it Double Pedro.
Never knowed that.
Ohh. Yaah. Double Pedro. Is that it.
Five o' trumps yer Pedro, five o'  same color's yer left,...
(across him) Yah.
...ranks jest below yer five o'  trumps, each count ya ten points.
Yaahh. Suure I played it. (sharp pause) For money you mean?
Either way suits me.
Let's just play for fun.
Suits me.
(voice up) Just for fun, if that suits you.
Fun. Yah. Yah. I play.
(o.s.) Fine.
They all pull up their chairs. The Swede laughs shrilly a strangely.
He looks up quickly at the Swede (lens)
His jaw drops open, his head and eyes toward the Swede.
Not really looking except very quietly, 'as if from under his eyes', holding the cards with still fingers.
His hands still suspended motionless.
Well, let's get at it. Come on now!
Faint nods of agreement and shiftings forward as they beg to cut for deal.

He is a very fast shuffler. We watch him finishing one wh and through another, then he puts the cards toward the Sw for the cut, the CAMERA FOLLOWING AND PULLING BACK. The S slowly and seriously cuts the deck three ways as the CAME RECEDES AND RISES to take in his face and Johnnie's. He i smiling at Johnnie who seems about to speak -- not quarre somely exactly -- but lets it go and starts gathering in deck.

Johnnie deals very rapidly, three cards to a man at a tim the CAMERA following the cards around and the eyes of the four men following too. The Swede picks up his first thre cards as quick as they fall, the others leave theirs on t table. He instantly takes them in so close to his chest t in looking, he is like a woman looking down the front of dress.
They all pick up their cards and look and arrange them.
The Swede's VOICE names the trump suit.
The players discard, face up. (They have been dealt nine  cards each). They lay them down almost simultaneously: Th Easterner 7, the Cowboy 7, the Swede 5 and Johnnie 8. The Cowboy WHISTLES softly.
Johnnie fills for them. 4 to the Easterner, 4 to the Cowb and 1 to the Swede.
He robs the deck for 5 cards.

The Swede leads, Johnnie lays a card out, then the Easter then the Cowboy. The Cowboy lays his first card down quie but already his face, especially the eyes, have strangely altered. He seems essentially quite a gentle guy but the  usually rather slow eyes are bright and ruthless. THE SHO CONTINUES to the Swede as he rakes in a trick and leads h next card; past Johnnie for his and the Easterner for his the Cowboy who, with a face like the Archangel Michael go Satan, WHAMS down his card.

The instant the card hits the table with its startling no the Swede jumps with fright, is mad at being scared and f a smoldering, mean eye at the Cowboy. Johnnie is mildly startled and quietly amused, much aware the reactions of the other two. The Easterner flinches with startlement; mildly annoyed; little annoyed with himself for being annoyed; an automat and almost successful effort to show nothing.
As the hand and card WHAM down again, Johnnie's eyes go t the Cowboy, more amused. The two others take care not to  look up.
He is on top of the world.

SOUND of shuffling. His face has begun to darken, swell a crease; he is looking dull daggers toward the Cowboy from under his brows; sore as a boil. It is clear the Cowboy h busted hell out of his bid.
SOUND OF cowboy's VOICE bidding. The Easterner is sizing up with care; he is a little annoyed and shaken, but a  disciplined man.
He is playing a card, eyes very watchful of his two oppon and still more amused. He knows how sore they are getting and how off-their-game it is putting them.
Still more tickled with himself and more ruthless than be WHAM.
Bullet by golly.
Still more so than before. WHAM.
Reckon that'll learn ye.
A card lifted high to wham, then laid out quite gently.
Reckon we'll leave um take this-un  Johnnie-boy, sure looks like they  could use it.

WHAM on CLOSE UP OF SWEDE By now boiling internally, he  sullenly plays his card. WHAM on CLOSE UP OF EASTERNER Managing almost perfectly t control his wincing and hide his anger. WHAM on CLOSE UP OF JOHNNIE Eyes quick at Swede and the  Easterner, just managing to hold in his laughter. WHAM on CLOSE UP OF COWBOY Sweat bright on his forehead, tie and collar loosened, impervious to their anger; happy a clam. WHAM on CLOSE UP OF JOHNNIE He can no longer contain his  laughter. WHAM on CLOSE UP OF EASTERNER Looking pinched around the  nostrils and pretty sick.
Ready for the wham; a light card falls.
(o.s.) Reckon we can afford it.

The Swede does a quiet collapse equivalent to that of lea against a strong wind which suddenly stops; Johnnie's lau LOUDENS o.s. The Swede, still wearing coat and vest, is i great state of dishevelment, sweating hard, miserable; by now he is as mad at quiet cards as at whams and as mad at Johnnie as at the Cowboy. WHAM on CLOSE UP OF THE EASTERNER His vest unbuttoned, un to sit up straight any more; he is smiling bitterly; SOUN of Johnnie's laughter intensifies o.s.
Weak with laughter, but still at it; by now his shirt is  unbuttoned down to the waist and he is sweating with laug laughing as much at the Cowboy as at the others.

His large, thick, long red neck sprouting enormously from tie and collar still more awry than before; aware he too being laughed at but stolidly and hugely pleased with him eyes to all three players: WHAM. The CAMERA lifts and loses his head and shoots over it an the slickening SOUND of the cards, up the length of the r centering on the window and the wild snowing outside: ord full daylight: HOLD, fading the card SOUNDS and the laugh and the beat of wham almost to inaudibility and whiffling the blizzard SOUNDS:

Well into the beginning of dusk; a melancholy and slightl sinister light through the window, touching everything  visible; fade card SOUNDS in and up, and Johnnie's laught much more tired and habituated; LOWER CAMERA to take Cowb head, the kind of guy who never knows when a joke stops b a joke; another full-sized WHAM;

head_text.speaker/title: CUT OVER JOHNNIE'S FIRST WORDS TO:

text: MEDIUM SHOT -- SWEDE, JOHNNIE, EASTERNER from COWBOY'S AN Johnnie is practically sick with laughter; the other two beat-out and sick to death of it. They are almost sorer a Johnnie than at Cowboy and show it in their hangdog glanc at him.
Haahh, Lordy, I could die laughin'!

The Swede, and even the Easterner, flick him bitter glanc Johnnie relaxes still more limp in his chair, tears on hi cheeks, catching their hard looks and totally unmoved; ju another whicker of laughter at them.
(o.s.) Your deal Johnnie, and you'd better  give the other boys some cards for a  change. They sure look like they  could use a few.
Gett'n' chilly in here. (looking up and around) Hey, it's gett'n' dark.
They all look up and around towards the window and realiz it for the first time. Johnnie gets up; behind the follow lines he puts on coal:
Hmm! (he acts bemused coming  out of deep  concentration on the  cards)
A pause. From mid-room, in the fading light, we watch the watching the darkening, the strange light on their faces, the faces calming, even saddening a little.
(quietly) Snow sure does look blue, this time  a day.
The Easterner nods; a little surprised that Cowboy notice it.
Funny, cause snow ain't blue, it's  white. Snow white, like they say.
The Easterner smiles very quietly.
Reckon it's the light.
(nods; then all but  whispers) Yes.

The Swede, throughout this, is deeply still and withdrawn his face is preparing, inconspicuously, the strange line which he will re-enter the conversation. Johnnie, finished with the stove, crosses between CAMERA the table to side table o.s., their eyes follow him quiet light changes on their faces as, o.s., he lights and turn up a lamp.

As he finishes with the lamp and leaves the shot, HOLD a  moment on the lamp, its light tender and magical in the f day, and disclosing their faces, still bemused in the  ambiguous lightings of the last daylight and of lamplight in daylight. There is a soft, strange point of light in e eye.

Johnnie reseats himself, pulls up, and gets the deck read for shuffling; and their heads turn back from the lamp to the game. Johnnie, realizing the shift and slowing of moo and influenced by it, dawdles a little, more or less idli and toying with the cards. A deeply pleasant and comforta silence, tinged with the melancholy of dusk.

Beginning on the Easterner's quiet face; then the Cowboy' (past him we see the whole room and the darkening window) then the Swede whose strange eyes still catch the lamplig then Johnnie, ready to resume playing but waiting for the This shot is to crown and epitomize the mysterious yet  peaceful mood -- which is now broken by
(o.s., quiet and musing) I suppose there have been a good  many men killed in this room.
A short, electrified pause.
(quietly) How's that?
ANGLE All looking at the Swede sharply.
His eyes move to the Cowboy and the Easterner, then to  Johnnie.
I said, I suppose there have been a  good many men killed in this room.
A short pause.
What the divil're you talkin' about?
astounded and intensely curious.
(a blatant laugh,  full of false courage  and defiance) Oh, you know what I mean, all right!
I'm a liar if I do!
(very much the son of  the proprietor) Now, what might you be drivin' at,  Mister?
(winks at Johnnie, a  wink full of cunning) Oh, maybe you think I have been to  nowheres. Maybe you think I'm a  tenderfoot?
I don't know nuthin' about you and I  don't give a whoop where you've been.  All I got to say is I don't know  what you're drivin' at. There hain't  never been nobody killed in this  room.
(a sudden swing of  his whole head toward  the Swede) What's wrong with you, Mister?

ALL FROM SWEDE'S ANGLE, AT SPEED OF FLICKING EYES: Cowboy with the Easterner in the b.g. and slightly blurred focus Johnnie with the Easterner in the b.g. and slightly blurr focus; the Easterner alone, in sharp focus; all are tight looking into the Swede's eyes but the Easterner is the on one who looks at all "concerned" or in the least sympathe

He seems to feel he is "formidably menaced". He sends an  appealing glance to the Easterner. Start very quietly, br up ever louder, o.s. SOUND of "some loose thing beating  regularly against the clapboards" -- "like a spirit tappi
(mockingly, to  Easterner) They say they don't know what I mean!
(impassively) I don't understand you.
Johnnie and the Cowboy exchange glances and look to the S
(shrugging) Oh, I see you are all against me. I  see --

During the shrug, the CAMERA creeps a little to the r. pa the Easterner and bores in on the Swede and the Cowboy, t latter in deep stupefaction and rising impatience. By the time of the second "I see", the CAMERA loses the Swede  entirely and the Cowboy, in solitary CLOSE UP, slams down his hands on the board:
Say, what're you gett'n' at, hey?
WHIP CAMERA TO SWEDE AND TILT UP as he springs up with th celerity of a man escaping from a snake on the floor.
(standing in tilted  close up from the  angle of the center  of the table) I don't want to fight! I don't want  to fight!

They have saved the table from his sudden getting up; the hands clench it. The Cowboy stretches his long legs insol and deliberately. He jams his hands deep in his pockets. spits, twisting past his shoulder, into the cuspidor almo at the Swede's feet.
(quiet and contemptuous) Well, who in tarnation thought you  did?

The Cowboy's turned head and jaw in floor of shot at the  beginning; slowly CREEP ON THE SWEDE, gaining a little, l the Cowboy, as the Swede backs rapidly toward the wall ne the coat room, in his eyes, "the dying swan look". The TA outdoors is VERY LOUD by now.
(voice quavering) Gentlemen, I suppose I am going to  be killed before I can leave this  house! I suppose I am going to be  killed before I can leave this house!
SOUND of door opening o.s.

head_text.subj: SCULLY, FROM SAME POSITION, NEW ANGLE

text: He enters from his office near the front door. He pauses surprise.
(eagerly and swiftly;  head turning to answer  Scully) These men are going to kill me.
Kill you! Kill you? What are you  talkin'?
The Swede makes the "gesture of a martyr".
What is this, Johnnie?

(sullen, but looking  at Scully) I dunno. I can't make no sense to  it. (eyes drifting, he  begins to shuffle  the cards with an  angry snap) He says a good many men have been  killed in this room, or something  like like that. And he says he's  goin' to be killed here too. I dunno  what ails him. He's crazy, I shouldn't  wonder.
Kill you? Kill you? Man, you're off  your nut.
Oh, I know. I know what will happen.  Yes, I'm crazy -- yes. But I know  one thing...
An almost lightning quick shot of all of them from the Sw angle.
...I know I won't get out of here  alive.
HOLD on him, sweating and full of dread, at least three  seconds of silence.
He "draws a deep breath, as if his mind was passing into last stages of dissolution".
(whispering almost to  himself) Well, I'm doggoned.
Wheeling suddenly on Johnnie.
You've been troublin' this man!
(loudly; with grievance) Why good night, I ain't done nothin  to 'im!

head_text.subj: PAST SCULLY, STANDING, JUST BEYOND COWBOY

text: (one step forward;  stops) Gentlemen, do not disturb yourselves.  I will leave this house. I will go  away, because --
He accuses them dramatically with his glance.
-- Because I do not want to be killed.
(wheeling, furious,  to Johnnie) Will ye tell me what's the matter ye  young divil? What's the matter,  annyhow? Speak out!
Blame it! I tell you I don't know.  He -- he says we want to kill him,  and that's all I know. I can't tell  what ails him.

Never mind Mr. Scully; never mind. I  will leave this house. I will go  away because I do not want to be  killed. Yes, of course, I am crazy --  yes. But I know one thing! I will go  away. I will leave this house. Never  mind, Mr. Scully; never mind. I will  go away.

You will not go away. You will not  go away until I hear the reason of  this business. If anybody has troubled  you I will take care of him. This is  my house. You're under my roof, and  I will not allow any peaceable man  to be troubled here.

Never mind, Mr. Scully; never mind.  I know you don't want trouble, but  you can't stop them. Nobody can stop  them, not God Himself. (sad wag of head) No Mr. Scully, I will go away. I do  not wish to be killed. I'll get my  baggage.
The screen is empty for a moment, then Scully darts into shot, half across the screen.
(peremptorily) No, no!

Angle for the Swede's "beyond words" backward glance at  Scully, and his sad and deliberate exit. Scully still transfixed in c.s., looking after the Swede; SOUND of a door closing and the Swede's slow feet on the  stairs. He holds, slowly turns, walks slowly and very  impressively back toward the table, CAMERA with him.
Now. What does this mane?

head_text.subj: THE THREE FROM SCULLY'S STOOPED, INVESTIGAT

text: (rather loudly and  almost in unison) Why, we didn't do nuthin' to him!
So close that Johnnie and the Cowboy are not in the shot.
(coldly) No? You didn't?
Why this is the wildest loon I ever  see. We didn't do nuthin' at all. We  were jest sett'n' here playin' cards,  and he...
(o.s., interrupting) Mister --
(solemnly) Mister: what has these boys been  doin'?
(slowly, after a long,  careful pause) I didn't see anything wrong at all.
PULL BACK to frame in Johnnie and the Cowboy; vindicated a little smug.
Miserably and desperately chewing that one over: a sudden outburst.
(howling) But what does it mane? (to Johnnie) I've a good mind to lather ye for  this, me boy!
(frantic) Well what've I done?
(scornfully) I think you are tongue-tied.
He looks at them 1-2-3 again, turns on his heel; walks to the stairway door and out of shot, CAMERA LIFTING a trifl to follow.
Over SOUND of closing door and Scully's climbing feet, ea looks from one to the other, speechless, dumbfounded.

The Swede's leaning left shoulder; he is strapping his va A LITTLE NOISE; he straightens up wheeling with a loud cr CAMERA following into CLOSE UP; his terrified eyes are fi just to the right of the lens.
He is carrying a small kerosene lamp which scare-lights h wrinkled face. He should "resemble a murderer" sufficient to startle even the audience.
Still sick with terror as Scully leaves the dark corridor and enters the lighted room.
Man! Man! Have you gone daffy?
Carrying his lamp; ordinary lighting of room.
Oh, no! Oh, no! (short pause) There are people in this world who  know pretty nearly as much as you do --  understand?
On his deathly pale cheeks are two spots, "as sharply edg as if they had been carefully painted". His eyes brighten almost as if with tears. For a moment his mouth trembles; then he makes it firm.
(quiet, solemn,  profoundly sad) Just one rule, Mr. Scully, and I  learned it young. Don't never trust  nobody. Be ready for anything.
He looks at Scully, both daring him to contradict, and  desperately pleading for assurance that this is not so.
My father beat that into me. That's  why I'm alive today. (his pleading,  forbidding look  intensifies)

Scully means well but all this is far beyond him; besides he is wholly wrapped up in the immediate situation. He is studying the Swede very carefully, in deep concern and  puzzlement. After a moment he puts his lamp on the table sits on the edge of the bed, CAMERA SWINGING to keep him  centered. MEDIUM SHOT -- SCULLY R.S. -- SWEDE STANDING L.S.

(ruminatively) By cracky, I never heard of such a  thing in my life. It's a complete  muddle. I can't for the soul of me  think how you ever got this idea  into your head. (a short silence) And did you sure think they were  going to kill you?
(scans him as if he  wants to see into  his mind. At last,  with a great effort) I did.
He turns again to the valise straps, back to Scully. His  whole arm shakes, his elbow wavering like a bit of paper.
(banging impressively  on the footboard of  the bed) Why, man, we're goin' to have a line  of illictric street-cars in this  town next spring.
(stupidly, vacantly) A line of electric street-cars. (he gets busy on the  other strap)

And there's a new railroad goin' to  be built down from Broken Arm to  here. Not to mention the four churches  and the smashin' big brick  schoolhouse. Then there's the big  factory, too. Why in two years  Rrhahmpr'll be a metropolis.
(he straightens up  and politely awaits  the termination of  the foregoing lines) Mr. Scully, how much do I owe you?
(sore; getting up) You don't owe me one red cent.
Yes I do. (he takes coins from  his pocket and offers  them to Scully, who  snaps his fingers in  disdainful refusal;  their eyes rest on  the open palm between  them, gazing in a  strange fashion)

The open palm, very heavy and alive, tailors' marks and  callouses on it, trembling faintly; three quarters on it. MEDIUM SHOT -- SCULLY R.S. -- SWEDE STANDING L.S. Their eyes lift from the open palm and meet strangely in  silence.
(quietly) I'll not take your money. Not after  what's been goin' on here.
All of a sudden he begins to look very crafty. The Swede  watches the change in his face with deep uneasiness.
His eyes to Scully, looking still more uneasy.
Looking still more crafty.
Here, here! (he turns and picks  up the lamp, CAMERA  following, and comes  back close again,  beckoning, guileful) Come with me a minute.
Recoiling in overwhelming alarm.
Pressing closer; wheedling, crafty.
Yes! Come on! I want you to come and  see a pitcher -- just across the  hall -- in my room.
Swede very close, his teeth shaking like a dead man's; PU BACK to bring in Scully very close in almost the posture a Judas about to plant the kiss, eyes slantwise up to the taller man.
Come on. There's nuthin' to be afraid  of: Come on. (he starts for the  door)
PULL CAMERA BACK and lead them out through the door, Scul holding his lamp high, the Swede following with the step one hung in chains.

The lamp is thrust through darkness high upward against t wall of Scully's room, picking up first a sliding swatch ornate wallpaper, then a ridiculous photograph of a littl girl, the figure graceful as an upright sled-stake. She i the hue of lead. She leans against a balustrade or gorgeo decoration. The formidable bang to her hair is prominent.
There, that's the pitcher of my little  girl that died. Her name was Carrie.  She had the purtiest hair you ever  saw.
PULL BACK to take Scully close, looking up.
(continuing) I was that fond of her, she --
Scully's eyes to the Swede, SWING CAMERA onto the Swede,  Scully beyond him. He is not looking either at Scully or picture but is keeping keen watch on the gloom at the rea

(continuing) Look, man! That's the pitcher of my  little girl that died. Her name was  Carrie. (Swede is around,  reluctant, scared,  uninterested. As his  eyes lift toward the  picture, SWING CAMERA  to lose him, and  past Scully, and to  new picture as Scully  continues) And then here's the pitcher of my  eldest boy, Michael... (graduation shot, cap  and gown, a smart,  shrewd, ambitious- looking young Irishman) ...he's a lawyer in Lincoln, an'  doin' well. I gave that boy a grand  eddication an' I'm glad for it now.  He's a fine boy. Look at him now.

Ain't he bold as blazes, him there  in Lincoln! An honored and respected  gintleman. (turning to the Swede) An honored and respected gintleman. (he smites the Swede  jovially on the back;  the Swede smiles  faintly, lugubriously) Now, there's only one thing more. (he turns from the  wall and the Swede  turns his head back  to CAMERA to look.)
He drops to knees, plants his lamp on the carpet, and bur under the bed.
(muffled) I'd keep it under me piller if it  wasn't fer that boy Johnnie.
(o.s.) Then there's the old woman -- Where  is it now?

head_text.subj: SCULLY'S HIGH RUMP AND THE LAMP

text: (from under bed) I never put it twice in the same  place. Ah, now, come out with ye.
Scrambling and grunting he backs from under the bed dragg an old coat rolled into a bundle, flecked with lint.
I've fetched him!
He starts brushing off flecks of lint.

The Swede, his eye sharpening. Scully brushes off a last little whisk of lint and carefu unrolls the coat, and extracts from its heart a large yel brown whiskey bottle. He holds the bottle against the  lamplight. Reassured that nobody has been at it, he thrus it upward with a generous movement toward the Swede.

He is about to eagerly clutch this element of strength bu suddenly jerks his hand away and casts a look of horror u Scully. Scully gets to his feet, lamp in one hand, bottle in the  other, and takes a step toward the Swede.
(affectionately) Drink.
Lighted only by the lamp. A silence. Scully clamps the bo under the lamp-bearing arm, twists out the cork, holds ou both bottle and cork.
Drink!
Suddenly the Swede laughs wildly. He grabs the bottle, sc it into his mouth.
Small, worried, the beginning even of a look of fright.
In witch-like lamplight: bottle tilted high, lips curling around the opening, throat working and SOUNDS of his  swallowing: his eyes, burning with hatred, fixed upon Scu
A long astounded silence. The Easterner lights a cigarett
(almost reverently) That's the dod-dangdest Swede I ever  see!
(contemptuously) He ain't no Swede.
Well what is he then? What is he  then?
(astutely and  deliberately) It's my opinion he's some kind of a  Dutchman.
Johnnie is impressed; the Easterner, interested and amuse by both of them, covers his amusement.
(continuing) Yes, sir, it's my opinion this feller  is some kind of a Dutchman.
(sulkily) Well he says he's a Swede anyhow. (to Easterner) What do you think?
Oh, I don't know.
Well, what do you think makes him  act like that?
Why, he's frightened. (he flicks ash in  spittoon)
CAMERA slowly creeps them into close up.
(continuing) He's clear frightened out of his  boots.
(in unison) What at?
The Easterner reflects.
(again in unison) What at?

(slowly turning the  cigarette between  his fingertips,  scrutinising the  coal) Oh, I don't know, but it seems to me  this man has been reading dime novels  about the wild west, and he thinks  he's right out in the middle of it --  the shootin' and stabbin' and all. (he looks to the Cowboy  and then to Johnnie)
(deeply scandalized) But this ain't Wyoming, ner none o'  them places. This is Nebrasky.
(sore and eager) Yeah, an' why don't he wait till he  gits out West?
(laughs quietly) It isn't so wild out there even --  not in these days. But he thinks  he's right in the middle of hell.
He is quiet. Johnnie and the Cowboy muse long.
(after a silence) It's awful funny.

Yeah, this is a queer game. I hope  we don't git snowed in... (Easterner glances  toward front window) ...'cause then we'd have to stand  this here man around with us all the  time. That wouldn't be no good. (he wags his head) No sir ree bob tail.
I wish Pop ud throw him out.
Couldn't do that. He ain't done  nuthin'. Not edsackly.
I don't care. I don't like him.
You or me neither.

They are alerted by SOUND of loud stomping on the stairs, o.s. Scully's ringing voice ad lib, no words audible; the Swede's laughter. They all look quickly to the stairway d then "vacantly" at each other.
Gosh!
SOUND of door opening o.s.; all look sharply toward it.
Scully, flushed and anecdotal, swings into the room and d toward the table like all three musketeers. The Swede fol laughing bravely.

(more or less over  his shoulder) An' then he sez, sez, 'Oh', he sez,  'I've got to bring thim along to  hould the jackass,' he sez: 'He don't  like it.' (plenty of haw haw  from Swede and Scully) 'He don't like it', he sez! Wouldn't  that kill yez?
He don't like it, huh? Haw, haw,!  Durn good!
Scully is almost up to the stove, Swede close behind; CAM PULLS BACK to shoot past them at the seated men during  Scully's next line.
(sharply) Come now, move up and give us a chance  at the stove.
The Cowboy and the Easterner obediently sidle their chair to make room. Johnnie, keeping the board on his lap, simp arranges himself in a more indolent attitude.
Come, git over there.
Plenty of room without me movin'.
(roaring) An' you with the warmest spot in the  house?
(a patronising bully) No, no. Let the boy sit where he  likes.
(deferentially) All right! All right!
They exchange glances of wonder.
Anyhow, I don't know as I want to  sit with these people.
Just suit yourself Mister. We'd be  glad of yer company, but just suit  yourself. Liberty Hall, ye know. (he laughs nervously)
I want a drink of water.
(at once) I'll git it for you.
(contemptuously) Nahh, I'll get it for myself.

He walks off with the air of an owner toward and into Scu office. CAMERA LIFTING TO FOLLOW, shooting past tops of t heads of the seated men. As soon as he is out of sight Sc and CAMERA lean down quick and close into the group.
(in an intense whisper) Ye know what? Upstairs? I gave him a  little snort o' what's good for yez,  an' he thought I was tryin' to poison  'im!
(not lowering his  voice) Say, this makes me sick, why...
(finger to lips) Ssh!
(voice scarcely lowered) ...why don't you throw 'im out in  the snow?
Why, he's all right now. It was only  that he was from the East, and he  thought this was a tough place...
Looking with admiration toward the Easterner
(o.s.) ...That's all. He's all right now.
As the Cowboy speaks, the CAMERA SWINGS to include the  Easterner.
You were straight. You were onto  that there Dutchman, dead to rights.
Well, he may be all right now, but I  don't see it. Other time he was  scared, but now he's too fresh. Ain't  that right?
(o.s.) Sure looks like it to me.
Looks like to me he's bound to fall  off one side a th' hoss or t'other.
The Easterner nods quietly.
(o.s.) Why don't you kick him out, Pop?
A sharp INTAKE OF BREATH from Scully; all look up sharply
PULLING BACK with him as he leans down into group, hands knees, thundering at him with passionate solemnity.

What do I keep? What do I keep? What  do I keep? (he slaps one knee  impressively; shouts) I keep a hotel! A hotel, do ye mind?  A guest under my roof has sacred  privileges. He is to be intimidated  by none. Not one word shall he hear  that would prijiduce him in favor of  goin' away. I'll not have it. A NOTE ON THE FIGHT: This is to be a sensational fight bu not in any traditional melodramatic sense of that. It is  extremely violent but spasmodic, full of unskillfulness, very clumsy -- the clumsiness enhanced by heavy clothing by occasional veerings onto patches of glare-ice. Though violence is of itself shocking, the chief shock or sensat element is getting the shock of two essential amateurs, n fighters, in something close to mortal combat: almost as  disconcerting as if one saw a couple of clergymen trying beat each others' brains out. This can be arrived at thro the ice, heavy clothes, ungainliness and lack of skill. I is also clear that you can kill a man whether you know ho or not. Both soon learn that in such heavy clothing  practically all that's worth trying to hit is the head; t Johnnie, assuming that the Swede is soft in the middle, t pumping them into his belly with hard loud smacks of fist against leather. The fight is not shot in detail or from  either fighter's angle, but as the spectators see it -- n very clearly. SOUNDS of blows and breathings are way up.  Insofar as possible, the best fight would come of ad libb it, barring a few junctures necessary to the story. The two men crash together like bullocks and there is a  perplexity of flying arms. We so exaggerate the SOUND of crash that the audience feels it like a kick in the belly and instead of any sparring or fooling around they instan start socking with all their speed and strength. Both are evidently trying for instant and pulverizing victory; als it is very thoroughly a hatred-fight. They work with this intensity as long as their first wind and strength holds. They veer side to side and back and forth enough in this  first phase that the CAMERA has to waver back and fill a  little, but nothing special -- except that it should not  frame them too carefully or neatly. The spectators, movin slightly when they need to, get into and out of shot ad l As they first crash and sock, a squeezed curse, -- it is  indistinguishable from which fighter. (For 'curse,' try s the first 2/3rds of "God" and "Christ" simultaneously, fr between tight teeth).

In mid-yowl and in mid-air; he lands on his feet again an hands on knees, looks intently.

(barring him) Kape back.

(coldly) Bill.

He is leaning heavily against a little wind-waved tree,  breathing like an engine, while his savage and flame-lit  eyes roam from face to face... a mysterious and lonely fi waiting... a splendor of isolation in his situation.
His sad but awed reaction, still looking toward the Swede his eyes turn to Johnnie.

Almost vertical over Johnnie as Scully and the Cowboy (wh has come opposite Scully) gently turn him onto his back,  their arms sustaining his head and chairing his shoulders little off the ground. Nothing from Johnnie. With his free right hand, tenderly as a woman, Scully smo back the clotted hair from the smeared, smooth, very youn looking forehead, and wipes away the ice and snow. Johnnie gasps and opens his eyes languidly.

As Scully gets to his feet, PULL CAMERA up and back to ce on him in MEDIUM CLOSE UP from the Swede's angle. Cowboy Johnnie low in r.s., the Easterner still closer in l.s.,  watching Scully. Scully straightens up.

The Easterner's eyes to the Swede, quickly back to Scully

Without replying, he leaves his tree, walks toward and pa them, CAMERA keeping him centered, the Easterner's eyes  following him, Scully not moving or looking at anything:  CAMERA SWINGS with the Swede (who passes between it and t hotel wall) and HOLDS ON HIM as he passes out of the lee the house to where the wind hits him like a Mack truck an tears at his clothes; he disappears bowed-over deeply, ba to the storm.

His crumpled, leaning face, from Johnnie's angle.

His eyes are still on the Swede's face but are out of foc He has not moved since his surrender. His face has change only in looking still older, more stern, more sad, more  tragic. He lowers his eyes and stoops toward Johnnie.

The Cowboy has him half-sitting; Cowboy's profile r.s.,  Scully's comes into shot at left; Johnnie's eyes are avoi everything. Scully puts out a hand toward an instinctive  caress and quickly withdraws it.

Did I hurt... hurt him any?

From just above and ahead of them as they flounder along  past the faзade of the hotel toward the door. Storm SOUND up. After another couple of step Johnnie is about to fall: the Cowboy comes swiftly to him obviously shouting something the screaming wind tears awa from us; Johnnie fights him off furiously and lunges ahea CAMERA stooping swiftly as he falls: the Cowboy swiftly t him; Scully's heartsick face is disclosed as the Cowboy  stoops, and Easterner's frozen face behind him as Scully  leans; the CAMERA on down to the Cowboy and Johnnie as th Cowboy picks him up as if he were a child and staggers wi him up the drifted steps, Johnnie protesting violently, S hurrying ahead to get the door open.

From same position of last interior shot, from deepest in corner. On the stove, and beyond it, the dining room door. (crossing to him) Did he hurt ye child did he hurt ye  so bad? (she squats in front  of him) Lookit me Johnnie let me see yez. (Under this Johnnie,  from his first hearing  of them, has been  shrinking into himself  and now mutters across  her line)

But she is tugging at his wrists and putting a hand under his forehead to lift his face while he still groans, head muffled in hands,
Please! Please! Quit it! Le' me be!

But he knows there's no use and she gets his face up (awa from us) and gives a close quick look and then a low keen wail as tears spring out of her and she turns loose of hi stubborn humiliated head to bring her hands incompletely  toward the primordial gesture of tearing her hair at the  temples.

(hands distrait in  the uncompleted  gesture: a wailing  sob) Ohh, me boy! Me little boy! And him  sitchy charmer! Lookit 'im Katy!  Jist lookit that! Ohh ain't it  dreadful, did you ever see sitch a  starin' horror!

With "and him sitchy charmer," CAMERA PULLS BACK and up a little; through the rest of her lines and, the CAMERA, fr the same position, does quick flicking shots like glances the eye, centering reactions of one or another of the men turn and of the daughter -- shots A, B, C, et seq. The  daughter meanwhile is horning in ad lib with "Ohh," and " and "Johnnie dear," "ain't it just awful," "it's a sinful shame," etc., and by a violence of gesture and voice, Mrs Scully drags CAMERA (by quick cut and a shade belated) ba to MEDIUM CLOSE UP of herself past Johnnie's bowed head.
As she flings herself on her knees before Johnnie, catche his face between her hands, already talking loudly.
(in a mixture to her  son and the room at  large) Crazy ye are, jist outa yer mind,  an' him a man twice his age an' size,  the great bullyin' murderer...
(across her lines, in  rage, humiliation  and disgust) Get away, cut it out, quit it I tell  ya, I ain't hurt bad, I'm all right...
(leaning weakly into  shot, aghast with  disgust and sympathy  for Johnnie; in a  weak voice) Molly! (she neither hears  nor sees him) Molly! Please! Molly! Hush now! Molly!  Not here. Molly!
Mrs. Scully does a slow take on him when she finally hear him, cuts off her former lines and whips her head at him.

(with cold fury) Shut up an' keep outa this, you!  Haven't ya done enough, standin' by  while a man half kills my baby boy? (her eyes rake all of  them) Crazy men! Bloodthirsty brutes! (her daughter echoes  her less noisily, ad  lib)
Mrs. Scully starts bustling up from her knees, CAMERA RIS with her.
(rising) Poor darlin'! Crazy boy, brawlin'  young fool, now jist come with mother,  gently darlin', come darlin', kin ye  walk, son? Come on, let's bathe the  poor blood off an' fix 'im up comfy.

Johnnie meanwhile is still protesting ad lib and is tryin at least to walk alone, as he had with the men, but not a chance; they wholly disregard his gestures of pride, his  efforts to shake them off. With ad libs of "Silly boy," a such, they cling to him like limpets, helping him out pas the stove and thence toward the dining room door. They reach the far side of the stove from the CAMERA
(straightening;  reproachfully) Shame be upon you, Patrick Scully!  Yer own son, too! Shame be upon you!
(ad lib) Shame, shame.
Scully has huddled meekly out of their path but now comes close to the stove as if he needed the warmth.
(gently, almost  inaudibly, meeting  no eyes) There, now! Be quiet now!
Shame, I say. Shame.

They turn toward the door on the far side of the stove; t CAMERA continues its crabwise glide and stops when stove  centers and blanks out screen, but SWINGS to HOLD them as they half-carry Johnnie back through the dining room door side and back-to the CAMERA; the door closes.

Over the SOUND of the closing door cut to a new angle, fr the same position, MEDIUM CLOSE of the survivors. His head is bowed; he wags it sl sighs very deeply; head still. The Cowboy, deeply sad and embarrassed, walks slowly arou a farther chair and sits, facing the CAMERA, staring at t stove. No answer.

He roots under his coat and deep into his britches-pocket slaps down a coin, and tosses off the new drink, eyes  following the Barkeeper.
Putting the coin through a highly-nickeled cash register  with a brilliant clanging of the bell.

As he finishes his second drink; he is heavier now yet st tremendously elated and at peace with himself: he pivots  eyes and head in a slow benign sweep down the bar and in direction of the table, looking toward the men, o. s., wi towering benign vanity and self-confidence, and friendly  interest. A pause. The Barkeeper is looking toward the table; the Swede at t Barkeeper. The Swede is trying to cogitate. The Swede is sweating a little; the booze is getting to h now; his breathing is a little heavier.

Well, I guess I'll have another drink. (he pours, a heavier  slug than before but  slower and, raising  his glass, needing  company bad but trying  to make it seem  casual, he eyes  Barkeeper o.s.) Have something?

He walks unsteadily up the bar for the cloth, toward the  edge of the shot, while the Gambler walks even more slowl to the bar; his back, like his front, expressive of terri shock and incredible control.

(in an unearthly calm,  dry voice with a  scratchiness  underneath) Charlie, you tell 'em where to find  me. I'll be home, waiting for 'em.

The Barkeeper tries to speak; he can't; he nods, then nod again. As he comes through the swinging doors, advances a couple paces, and stops dead in his tracks as his eyes find the  Swede. An impulse to go to him is instantly arrested; it so clear that he is beyond help. Almost unconsciously, he sets down his traveling bag. A freezing anguish of guilt  enters his still face. After a sufficient pause to make clear they did not come  with him, Scully, Johnnie and the Cowboy come in, quietly but winded. They also look, see, and are silent. They try subdue their breathing. They have left the street door op and we can see that there is no more storm or SOUND outsi The Easterner is aware when they come in; we feel that he even knows who they are. But throughout the scene, he nev shifts his eyes from the Swede; and they shift theirs onl rarely. Throughout, they stand behind Easterner. After a considerable silence:
(in a subdued voice) How did it happen?
The Easterner says nothing. A pause.
(quietly too) You ask me, that feller was lookin'  for trouble. An' he sure found himself  a plenty.
A pause.
(in a strange, vague  voice) Looking...? (more firmly, but  very quiet) Like all troubled men. (pause) And we helped him find it, and we  trapped him into it.
A pause. The three men behind now glance at each other.
(a little less subdued) See here, Mister.
The Easterner says nothing.
Just one thing.
(quietly) Go home.
Just one little thing. Johnnie an'  me live in this town. We don't want  no stories shpread around that ye...
(as quietly) Go home. Stop worrying. Tell whatever  story you please.
Ye mane ye -- ye won't...
Your conscience is your business.  Each one of you. My own is enough  for me to cope with.
They linger, unsure and weary.
(with deep exhausted  bitterness) So just go home now. Leave me alone. (pause) If you please!
A silence.
(quietly and solemnly) We didn't have no part in it.
The three shake their heads, but they don't look at each  other.
Every sin is a collaboration.  Everybody is responsible for  everything.
The three look unsurely at each other; they are obscurely abashed.
(with a slight gesture  and an almost  inaudible whisper) Come on.

Each looks a last time toward the Swede, each in his own  strange way, kind of gloomy, shy, foreboding reproach and resentment; and each, one by one, turns away from the CAM and walks quietly outdoors and out of the shot. With the absolute silence an even more fierce and living  quiet intensifies in the Easterner's face and becomes, as well, sorrow, pity, tenderness, a passionate desire for, hopelessness of, expiation.
